one_paragraph_summary: During this admission, a middle-aged woman with HIV on HAART, end-stage renal disease on thrice-weekly hemodialysis, prior trigeminal neuralgia/postherpetic neuralgia, and a history of atrial fibrillation was admitted from the emergency department for presyncope, shortness of breath, and hypotension noted while en route to her nephrology appointment. Initial evaluation showed low but stable blood pressure with normal oxygenation, a normal EKG, and a chest X-ray without acute pulmonary process. She was monitored on telemetry without arrhythmias, and transthoracic echocardiography showed normal biventricular systolic function and no structural cause of syncope. Laboratory studies revealed significant hypercalcemia (total calcium up to 12.7 mg/dL with elevated ionized calcium), elevated PTH in the setting of ESRD, and chronic macrocytosis with mild leukopenia and stable platelets. She underwent hemodialysis with no ultrafiltration, which improved her calcium and renal indices while avoiding further hypotension. A cosyntropin stimulation test demonstrated adequate adrenal reserve, ruling out adrenal insufficiency. CT head for new left-sided headaches showed no acute intracranial process, and abdominal ultrasound for nausea showed no acute hepatobiliary pathology but innumerable bilateral renal cysts. Blood cultures remained negative, and she stayed afebrile. Her presyncope and hypotension were attributed to dialysis-related volume shifts and medication effects; diltiazem was discontinued, and midodrine was initiated to support blood pressure. Nausea improved with antiemetics, and headaches were managed symptomatically. She was discharged home in stable condition, ambulatory and hemodynamically at her low baseline, with continued HAART and dialysis-related medications, new midodrine and prochlorperazine, and instructions for outpatient follow-up including vascular studies for leg pain.

problem_list.problem: Presyncope and hypotension, likely related to hemodialysis volume shifts and medication effects
problem_list.status_at_discharge: Blood pressure remained in her low baseline systolic 90–100 mmHg range, afebrile, with negative orthostatics, normal echocardiogram, no arrhythmias on telemetry, and improved symptoms; diltiazem was discontinued and midodrine 5 mg daily was started to support blood pressure.

problem_list.problem: Hypercalcemia in the setting of ESRD and secondary/tertiary hyperparathyroidism
problem_list.status_at_discharge: Initial total calcium was markedly elevated (12.7 mg/dL, ionized 1.45 mmol/L) with elevated PTH and normal alkaline phosphatase; after hemodialysis without ultrafiltration and continuation of cinacalcet, calcium improved to 11.2 mg/dL by discharge, with ongoing outpatient evaluation planned (vitamin D and PTHrP pending).

Remained dialysis-dependent with elevated creatinine and BUN; received an in-hospital hemodialysis session with no fluid removal to avoid hypotension, with improvement in creatinine and BUN post-dialysis; discharged to continue MWF dialysis with outpatient nephrology follow-up.

Clinically stable from an HIV standpoint; continued on atazanavir, lamivudine, ritonavir, and tenofovir with Bactrim prophylaxis; nausea thought partly related to HAART but improved with antiemetics; instructed to maintain adherence and follow with HIV/ID clinic.

problem_list.problem: Subacute left-sided headaches on background of trigeminal/postherpetic neuralgia
problem_list.status_at_discharge: CT head showed no acute intracranial process; headaches improved with symptomatic treatment including oxycodone; carbamazepine was trialed briefly then stopped; chronic right-sided neuralgia and ocular involvement continued to be managed with valacyclovir and erythromycin eye ointment; outpatient evaluation for possible migraine therapy recommended.

Nausea and two prior episodes of non-bloody emesis improved with ondansetron and prochlorperazine; liver enzymes and bilirubin were normal, and RUQ ultrasound showed no acute hepatobiliary pathology; patient was tolerating diet at discharge.

No atrial fibrillation observed on telemetry during admission; echocardiogram normal; diltiazem, presumed for rate control, was discontinued due to hypotension, with plan for outpatient reassessment if arrhythmia recurs.

problem_list.problem: Chronic macrocytosis with mild leukopenia and thrombocytopenia history
problem_list.status_at_discharge: CBCs showed macrocytosis (MCV ~105–107 fL) with stable hemoglobin and platelets and mild leukopenia; folate replacement continued; no evidence of acute hematologic process.

problem_list.problem: Right leg pain, concern for peripheral vascular disease
problem_list.status_at_discharge: Persistent right knee and thigh aching pain; ankle-brachial indices were ordered but not completed during the weekend; outpatient ABI testing recommended to evaluate for peripheral vascular disease.

key_tests_and_results.result: No acute pulmonary process; stable large-bore dual-lumen presumed dialysis catheter; no consolidation, edema, effusion, or pneumothorax.

Total calcium 12.7 mg/dL, phosphate 5.1 mg/dL, creatinine 7.5 mg/dL, BUN 41 mg/dL, sodium 139 mEq/L, potassium 4.9 mEq/L, bicarbonate 25 mEq/L, anion gap 20; hemoglobin 14.3 g/dL, hematocrit 42.4%, MCV 106 fL, platelets 162 K/uL, WBC 4.0 K/uL.

key_tests_and_results.test: Parathyroid hormone and related endocrine workup
key_tests_and_results.result: PTH elevated at 286 pg/mL with normal alkaline phosphatase (82 IU/L); serial cortisol levels including 13.2, 10.8, and 28.3 ug/dL after cosyntropin stimulation showed appropriate adrenal response, ruling out adrenal insufficiency.
Ionized calcium 1.45 mmol/L (elevated) with normal pH 7.35, confirming true hypercalcemia rather than artifact.
No acute intracranial process, no mass effect or hemorrhage; exuberant calcifications of the falx and tentorium cerebelli likely related to ESRD.
No acute hepatic or biliary process; normal gallbladder and bile ducts; innumerable bilateral renal cysts likely related to hemodialysis; small likely hemangioma in spleen.

key_tests_and_results.test: Serial calcium and renal function trends
key_tests_and_results.result: Calcium decreased from 12.7 to 12.0 to 10.0 to 11.2 mg/dL over the stay; creatinine and BUN fluctuated with dialysis (creatinine 7.5→10.0→4.7→7.0 mg/dL; BUN 41→62→22→45 mg/dL).
Peripheral blood culture showed no growth; dialysis line culture pending at discharge; no evidence of bloodstream infection during admission.

treatments_and_meds.details: Received an in-hospital hemodialysis session with no fluid removal to avoid exacerbating hypotension; this session contributed to lowering serum calcium and improving creatinine and BUN.

Hypercalcemia was managed by continuing cinacalcet 60 mg daily and sevelamer carbonate with meals and snacks, performing dialysis with calcium removal, and evaluating for secondary causes (PTH, vitamin D, PTHrP, cortisol). Calcium levels improved but remained mildly elevated at discharge.

treatments_and_meds.treatment_or_med: Evaluation and support for hypotension and presyncope
treatments_and_meds.details: Patient was monitored on telemetry, underwent echocardiography (normal), had orthostatic vitals checked (negative), and received a cosyntropin stimulation test (normal). Diltiazem was discontinued due to hypotension, and midodrine 5 mg daily was initiated to support blood pressure.

Continued home HAART regimen including atazanavir 300 mg daily, lamivudine 50 mg daily, ritonavir 100 mg daily, and tenofovir 300 mg weekly, along with sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim DS one tablet MWF for Pneumocystis prophylaxis.

Headaches and chronic neuralgia were treated with acetaminophen and oxycodone 5 mg as needed; carbamazepine XR was briefly trialed then discontinued; valacyclovir and erythromycin ophthalmic ointment were continued for prior VZV-related ocular involvement. Percocet was stopped to avoid excess acetaminophen, and oxycodone alone was prescribed at discharge.
Nausea and prior emesis were managed with IV ondansetron as needed during hospitalization and oral prochlorperazine 10 mg TID with meals, later continued as needed at discharge.

Continued sevelamer carbonate with meals and snacks for phosphate binding, cinacalcet for secondary hyperparathyroidism, Nephrocaps as a renal multivitamin, aspirin 81 mg daily, docusate and senna for bowel regimen, and Bactrim prophylaxis.
Received subcutaneous heparin 5000 units TID during hospitalization for venous thromboembolism prophylaxis.
